Though again, I want to note that the service was very good.   I also had mixed feeling about fit and finish of the property. The native southwest theme was fine but the decor was a bit out of date and in various states of repair. My suite was incredibly spacious, with great views, but it wasn't very comfortable. The couch was too hard to want to lounge on. The TV too small to see well. The dining table chairs were awkward, which made sitting at the table difficult. And the work desk was too small, with a chair that was loose and lacking in support. And the bed was too bouncy, which made sleep hard to come by. These are my own issues of course, but as subjective as they may be, I think people will readily see what I mean.  I've been fortunate to have stayed in many wonderful resort properties around the world, so at the risk of appearing immodest, I think I have a pretty good perspective on what makes a good resort and what doesn't. And while there were plenty of things I enjoyed about my stay, the Sheraton Wild Horse Pass isn't someplace I would seek out. Which is unfortunate, because the best resorts are places the make you look forward to returning to again and again. And Sheraton Grand at Wild Horse Pass isn't that.

Very upset that they roomed me below a room that was under construction. I had a nice jack hammer banging through the roof at 6:00AM. When I told the receptionist all she said was that is the "normal" time for them to start. Thank you for the non wanted wake up call and non wanted customer service. This is not a cheap hotel and gurantee you can find another resort that is newer and the same price.

Husband and I won some concert tickets for a show at the Wildhorse Pass Casino and since this hotel was full, we booked a room at the Sheraton.  We decided to splurge a little since we haven't been out for a while so decided to pay $160.00 for one night.   As usual, the resort is beautiful and very calming.  The room was nice, king size bed was fricking AMAZING and comfortable.  We only needed to sleep and weren't really here for all of the hotel amenities but super thankful that the bed and covers were awesome.  Now....here comes the BAD part.  For what you pay a night (even getting a deal on hotelfinder,com, etc.) you would think that the dang walls would be a little more soundproof than what they really are.  we could hear EVERYTHING!!!  Including the woman next door getting it on with her man whose headboard was against the same wall as our bed...   1a.m. in the morning this woman starts howling like an injured pig so stinking loud I could hear her breathing as well (again EVERYTHING).  People...please think vocal control when you are having sex in a resort room.   #1...she could do way better than what she sounded like., #2, if you are gonna go for broke, good god, come up with some better sex talk than what you were putting out.  Since I had to listen to it for 2 fricking hours before I started pounding on the dang wall!, #3 - PUT A SOCK IN IT!!!  It sounded like I was listening to the worst porno I have ever heard (and I have watched my fair share believe me - she would not cut it as a porn star for sure)  I will be much more hesitant to book a room here knowing that you have no sleeping peace during the night.  I was so disappointed. When we checked out, the lady asked us how are stay was and even after telling her it wasn't great, she just said, oh I am so sorry, I hope your next stay is better.  Seriously???  There won't be a next time.  Not for that price.  Luckily the bed helped a little.  Thank you for reading!!!
Had a great stay at SGWHP. Special thanks to Nicole and her crew for the fun kids activities!
Wonderful experience.  Awesome rooms and friendly staff.  Will elaborate more later.

If you looking for a short getaway vacation or whatever it called...lol...this is one of the place that you should try. The services was awesome, from the staff, the room was clean, the food was awesome too; hot and worth to wait! For the spa, sometimes you can get discount from Groupon, just keep tracking ;). I would love to recommended this place to try and I planned to go back to try something else!

Update. I'm taking back the nice things I said about the front desk staff. I should have waited to write my review until I checked out. Update (again):  I received a call from the housekeeping manager yesterday and he was very apologetic and assured me this was an aberration. He also gave me his contact information and asked for the opportunity to make it right by offering us a free night when we are again in the area. We likely won't, but it was a nice offer.

Came here for a work conference and couldn't be happier. The hotel staff was nothing but friendly.  This hotel is unique because the Native Americans really own the land so it keeps it more authentic. It's a beautiful place to stay.  There are a few places to eat on site. Lobby bar, Ko'Sin, Hanyo Pool Bar and one fancier place. I didn't eat at the fancy place on site but it sounds amazing. The pool bar is kid friendly and has frozen cocktails. Ko'Sin is upscale but not fancy (get the shrimp tacos) If you "go green" and opt not to use housekeeping during your stay, you can get SPG points which is cool.  The view of the sunset there is amazing although photos won't do justice.  Rooms were nice and included a personal patio with a table and chairs. The fitness center was nice and had plenty of space.  They had tennis courts, horseback riding and golf but I didn't do any of those. They have a water slide which looks very cool.  They provide towels for the pool so you don't have to use the in room ones.  The conference center is very nice and has lots of meeting rooms.  I would love to spend a few personal days here. They have a free shuttle to the casino and outlets for interested parties.

The self parking is close enough to the rooms but only one elevator which us located near the lobby. Most rooms are at the wings. They don't have any ramps for bringing up your bags from your car, just have to drag them up a curb and through gravel, then you must drag them up stairs or wheel them all the way back towards lobby for elevator then all the way back to your room. VERY inconvenient and impracticable!  The girl at the coffee/starbucks kiosk was very snobby and snooty. They have a green program where you can opt out if house keeping and get $5 gift card to spend at hotel. I called the desk two days in a row to opt out and housekeeping still came everyday, no $5 gift card either. The lack of a hotel gym is b.s. But the 3 mile running path is awesome. The pools are nice and the waiters are great by the pool. The water slide is fun and no lines! Walls are thin, you can hear the tv in the next room. Because of the pools and service at poolside,  I give this place 4 stars.

We visited for the casino only. It was a good place to get out of the heat and play, if you like to gamble. Free parking. It's not like Las Vegas so don't have expectations of free drinks being brought to you or 24/7 restaurants to eat at. Good choices of places to eat at from fast food to very expensive, exquisite dining. Very smokey, as all casinos are, but they do have a small non-smoking area. We had a good time. Mostly because we won. :)

Stayed three nights for an on site conference.  Service is what you would expect.  Room is slightly less than what you would expect.  Food is fine.  Here is what I did not expect: as an SPG gold level member to be put in one of the rooms farthest from everything with a view of the parking lot.  To be charged almost $300/night AND THEN an additional $13/day for wired, yes wired, internet access in my room.  Insult to injury $8 for a beer.  And the "authentic" Native American decor - cheesy.  Almost to the point of insulting.  Burning sage in the lobby?  Really?  In summary, I felt they took advantage of a group bringing them several hundred customers for four days.  Fail.
Had a wonderful spa day... Yoga, meditation, and massage... Service is excellent, amenities perfect and clean, and food/drinks deLicious... Be prepared to pay because it was pricey

TERRIBLE RESORT. I wish I could put no stars but I have to put at least one. My stay started by the security guard barging into the room after I asked for pillows. He was rude and very unprofessional.   Second off, my truck was STOLEN out of the front parking lot. Yes, stolen. When we notified security they proceeded to inform us that there are NO CAMERAS to "protect the privacy of the guests". What happens if someone were to get raped or murdered in their parking lot. We called the cops and they also informed us that 30 trucks have been stolen from the area in the past 2 months. After all of this has happened, they still don't have any cameras.   Sheraton should have compted my 2 suite 2 night stay at this world renowned resort that "celebrities stay at all the time". My own personal safety has been violated. And now I have to buy a new truck.

They take your money. Give you a confirmation number. You show up. They have your confirmation but no room available. Staff is excuse oriented instead of results oriented. Go to the Superbowl and no room. It became my 100% responsibility to find another hotel. They even put our luggage in someone else's room. You could not make up how badly this hotel fell flat on its face.

I recently stayed at your hotel and it was awesome the staff was extremely responsive and attentive and everything was great until the last day when we decided to take the kids swimming, one of the pools had something I don't know excessive chlorine or what but as a result two of my kids who were not wearing swimming googles had extremely painful and swollen eyes and we left the resort with kids in pain and crying. The two kids are traumatized and don't want to go swimming again. I was told by the attendants by the pool side that we were not the only ones who complained about it.  So our extremely wonderful stay turned into a disaster, the EMT on site visited us and did a report and he was also very helpful.  I know things like these happen so I wanted to give the  hotel a chance to fix this issues  but I never heard from them I emailed them about a month ago.

I am a big Sheraton fan and this location does not disappoint either. Very nice set up, location is perfect. Lots of activities, a perfect getaway. I gave it one less than perfect score because of the rooms that seem not only dated but quite small. Being a platinum SPG member, I am a bit spoilt with better rooms than this.

This hotel is very secluded, especially at night. The decor blends in very well with the locale and is Southwestern themed. Specifically Native Indian. Reminded me of Sedona AZ. They piped in music all over the property ( except in the rooms ) that was Native indian flutes. Charming but i felt bad for the workers who have to hear it 8 hours a day. They did a great job creating ambiance.   This place is huge and i spent quite a bit of time walking all over to finally find my room on the 2nd floor. The rooms were clean and the bed linens were 1st class and very comfy. My welcome letter included a voucher for breakfast which was quality ingredients all the way. Fresh eggs, sliced bacon, roasted and seasoned potatoes. The extra deep tub in the bathroom accommodated my large stature for a relaxing nice hot soak. Score.  This is definitely a 4 star hotel at a great rate. Really liked it was off the beaten path. Super relaxing and quiet.

Stayed here for a week for work. Overall heard wonderful things about the hotel but was less than impressed during my own stay.  Upon checking in, we had to walk nearly 7 minutes to our room to discover the card didn't work. We walked all the way back to the front desk with our luggage and got a new door key and then walked all the way back to our room to then discover the provided us to twins rather than the requested king. At which time we had to walk all the way back to the front desk where they said all rooms were filled and they could not help. Since the hotel was nearly dead other than the people at our work group we knew that was false and made a call the next morning and got a new room. Though the view was of parking lot.  While the rooms certainly are not my cup of tea, they fit the Arizona style and imagine most would find them appropriate.  The lobby is filled with some sort of spa spray that was absolutely nauseating.  The main highlight was the staff were all extremely nice and welcoming (aside from the late night check-in staff). Food was good, albeit not a lot of options compared to other hotels.  All in all, Arizona is not a place I would typically travel by choice, and I imagine this hotel is much better than the competition. My main suggestion would be to remove that horrible over powering aroma in the main lobby area.

This hotel is wayy out of the way from any city.  You would probably miss it driving along the freeway.  From the beginning of the entrance down to the front door is a long drive, so keep driving and you'll get to this mirage.  The people are courteous, making you feel welcome.  The lobby sees out to the Arizona landscape and swimming pool.  Unfortunately the dining is lacking.  There is horseback riding and other casinos nearby, along with a Spa, and plenty of places to ride your bike.  The pools have a slide and waterfalls, and outdoor food service + bar.  It is the very definition of a resort.  Sleeping under the stars like a cowboy, but also enjoying the luxurious life of a resort.

I came home and there was an extra $13.97(U.S.) charge on my credit card from this joint.  Is this a racket?  Did I not prepay some kind of Occupancy Tax for the Rez?    My charges upon checking out were: NY Times, Arizona Republic, bockkle of orange juice = $5.25 x 2   (I woulda drunk up a storm at the nifty pool-side bar, but it's Arizona and I gotta drive places, baby.)  Well I talked to Kristie in accounting (who must have a cool job, if you're going to be an accountant why not at a resort?) it was some kind of computerized mini-bar malfunction, she tells me, and zip--it's off the bill.    I appreciate this kind of service.

Wonderful hotel. Everyone was so accommodating and nice to ensure we had a great stay. I would definitely recommend it. My only disappointment was not getting a rsvn at Kai. Sunrise horseback riding Roger and Chuck were great! Spa day was lovely and Sheila did get job taking care of my niece so the adults could go to the adult only spa. The guys out front were awesome and my niece loved the s'mores night and the water slide. Great hotel!

Beautiful grounds, great service and staff, and immaculate room-- Excellent!  Stayed at the Wild Horse Pass Sheraton for a conference and it was a stellar experience. I've been to the hotel to dine at Kai (a religious experience), but this was my first stay. It's truly is a gem and the displays sharing the Gila River Indian Community's history was worth the time to learn.   Check-in was a breeze and the employee from Lahaina was as quick and courteous as I've seen. I was up to my room quickly, which was comfortable, well-appointed, and clean. Then made my way down to the patios and water areas for a reception, which was just enjoyable. The food and service staff were both awesome!  Had time permitted, I would have stayed longer to enjoy the pools, golf, and shopping at the tribe's Premium Outlet. Had to head home for work, instead. Will be back to enjoy things another day.  (One knock: The restaurant in the lower area of the lobby insisted on holding my credit card, which I wasn't comfortable with. The gentleman who served us was rather pushy and, so, I relented. But I believe it violates PCI standards for physical card security since it was out of site, with a service person, and unmonitored.)
This review is specific review for "Reflections" bar at the Wild Horse Pass. Tammy, the bartender makes an excellent Cadillac Margarita.

This resort is 4 stars for those within its price range, and 3 stars overall.  It's located in a very secluded area with at least 4 minutes of driving off any marked road to get to the resort. Clearly the reason is the golf course and the space it requires. There's also a few tiny manmade streams and a trail for "hiking" which is more like walking or running as its a flat and well-marked path.   There are 2 restaurants, one of which is the pretentious and well-known Kai which is known for rejecting diners based on the dress code. (Oh and also for its AAA rating). There is also a pool bar, a cafe, and a cafe at the spa.   Amenities also include a large outdoor pool and spa and a boat ride that leads to a somewhat cheesy "Wild West town." Additionally there is a free shuttle running every 15-30 minutes (depending on the season) to the Prime Outlets and casino, which are about 10 min away.   This resort overall has friendly service at the desk for check in and the general staff. I came for a conference and it feels adequate but not luxurious. The prices during early Sept (off season) were reasonable, under $130 / night. Given that this resort is comprehensive but by no means luxurious, I can't imagine paying more than $175/night. The resort fee is $25/night and doesn't even include spa facility access! (A paid day pass is required). Additionally, given that the resort is so secluded you lose the benefit of being able to explore Phoenix unless you have a car or disposable uber funds. (I prefer resorts with more walkability to local sites)  Overall a pleasant experience for a conference setting but I don't plan on booking my next vacation here!

Stayed after concert cheaper than dui driving home after, rooms were really clean and nice features, again it seems like the Arizona Casinos are slightly over priced on rooms, we at dinner and breakfast there in casino very large selection compaired to the other casinos, as far as show room it was nice chairs and seating could be different for my liking but it was funtinal

If I could go negative stars I would. No cold water for the showers (its 115 degrees outside); NO WIRELESS INTERNET (not even if you wanted to pay for it). A/C and toilets are both broken...I reported all to the front-desk and 12 hours later, still not fixed. .You couldn't pay me to step foot on this property again.

This is the fourth time I have stayed at this resort. The staff is always friendly and helpful. Every mother's day weekend my bf and I go there for a private event help by City of Hope to raise money for breast cancer awareness. The staff always is there helping us with whatever we need. The rooms are always clean and beautiful. I love the pool, since you have a few to choose from. There is a pool with a slide, water spouts and one that is a gradual. The drinks are pretty good too such as the prickly pair mojito. I suggest getting an order of fries and onion rings because it was a huge order for 8.50 and the onion didn't just come out with one bite leaving you with all the batter. I cannot wait to volunteer again and help at next year's event.

Third and final update from this resort from Hell. Needed aspirin for a sick family member at about 10 pm. No gift shop open of course. Should be no problem,  right?  Registration Desk had nothing that you would typically find at any two star Holiday Inn Express anywhere in country such as toothpaste, aspirin, toothbrush, razor, etc.   Here is another important element to this resort to keep in mind.  There are no restaurants, convenient stores, gas stations anywhere near it for miles. You are trapped here. Isolated. Nothing near here except tumbleweeds and the empty golf course.   Want a six pack? Have to drive 30 minutes round trip to nearest gas station/ convenient store. Want something besides their 16$ oatmeal or 30$ cheeseburger for a snack? You have to drive 20 minutes to Outlet Mall to find the food court.  Any full meal for anything is 40+$ per person and that is at the Casual restaurant on site.   So, in middle of night I had to drive 30 minutes round trip to the gas station to get aspirin for my sick family member.  Save your money and of headaches and stay anywhere else unless your company is stupid enough to pay for this place.

Wow, this resort did not disappoint!  I spent three days here this past week to attend a conference at this gem in the middle of the desert located on a reservation.   Everyone that works there was really pleasant, I didn't interact with them much, but in the handful of times I did, they all had cheery attitudes and treated me like I was royalty or something...at least that's how it came across in my head.  This resort is four stories high and very wide; my boss's room was located at the verrrry end of the other side of the hotel, far away from the conference center (a Segway would have come in handy for guests to get around).  Luckily, my room was up the stairs and around the corner, so I had time to run back to my room between seminars.  My room was cozy and I enjoyed the comfy king size bed once I crashed out.  I made use of the bath tub my first night and slept like a baby after;  it was a long day of traveling, getting situated, networking all followed by cocktails, an awesome surf & turf dinner and more networking.  This resort is really nice and relaxing.  I was there for a conference with hundreds of other Human Resource professionals from other colleges and universities throughout the U.S. and it looked like everyone was genuinely having a good time and happy to be there.   There really isn't much nearby except the fairly new Wild Horse Pass Hotel & Casino (which can send a complimentary Lincoln Navigator shuttle over to pick you up in less than ten minutes, it took them six minutes to get me one night).  But the big pool that I had a view of from my room's balcony looked inviting; there was a big twirling water slide that the kids at the resort maximized their usage on.  Anyway, the hotel is beautiful, but pricey.  It was on my company's dime, but it would certainly be a nice getaway for anyone looking for a little rest and relaxation.  I'm not sure if I'll ever find myself back in Chandler anytime soon, but if I am, I know I'll want to stay at this fine establishment again.  Kudos to Starwood Hotels (which the Sheraton is part of) for going green and rewarding my Starwood Preferred Guest account with five hundred points for opting not to have housekeeping clean my room while I was a guest; I was hardly in my room so there wasn't much to clean anyway...besides, it's the Virgo in me to not be a slob.

Stayed here for a one night getaway after we were done having fun at the wildhorse pass casino. The resort is very beautiful and large! I loved the room we stayed in and the bed was heavenly and ranks up there as one of the best. the room is decorated in native american style and has all the amenities that you expect from a nice resort. I would stay here again but would come earlier to enjoy the rest of the resort.  The only thing I was not prepared to do was walk so far to our room and my feet were sore from dancing and the hubster was exhausted. Btw if your coming from the casino just turn right and keep driving until you see the Sheraton sign.

This place is beautiful and it has everything you need. I love to play the golf courses. Tough golf courses. Play them from the tips and you will know what professionals have every weekend. The pool is such a relaxing place to chill and have a margarita. And then there's Kai. I heard it's one of only 14 restaurants in the country that are both 5 Star and  Diamond.

This place has everything on the grounds: 6 swimming pools, a water slide, ponds, the Gila River, a boat taxi, spa, casino, equestrian center, golf courses, a gift shop, a deli/coffee shop, a lobby bar, and 4 restaurants. All the rooms each have a balcony with table and chairs. The rooms are equipped with 52" flat screen TVs. The bathrooms each have a tub and standup shower. Even though it was my first time in the Phoenix area, I didn't want to leave the resort. And even though we did spend 2/3 of our time on the resort (we were in town for a total of 4 days), we didn't get enough time to enjoy all the facilities. For $95/night (thanks, Expedia!), this was worth every penny! The spa is way overpriced, but the price of food was fair, especially at Hanyo Pool Bar & Grill.

I came here on a business trip I was less than impressed. They claim to be the #1 Sheraton in the nation for hospitality and quality service's....haha! Upon checking in they decided to hold my debit card for $200 a night in case of incidentals. Now if you have a credit card, they won't change you anything...rediculous! When I explained that I was on a business trip and that there would be no incidentals, the GQ guy behind the counter said "it's policy and if you don't like it, then you don't have to stay". I asked to speak to a manager and he told me no one was available...yeah right!! I think he was just on a power trip.   The room was nice nonetheless, but it smelled like smoke...grose! Especially for someone who has never smoked. But they made it a point to tell me it was a nonsmoking room while checking in and with the signs/cards all over the room.   Also, don't bring your gym cloths unless you want to take a hike to the facility (seriously) and then pay $20/day when you get there. Something they don't tell you on their website.   The pool is really cool, especially for kids with the twisty slide. They also have a fire pit to roast marshmallows. The best part of the whole trip was the boat ride to the Rawhide Ranch. The Ranch was ehh, but the boat driver was a riot with his awesome serenading voice. He is the reason for the additional star and that is it!   I'm sure glad that I wasn't footing the bill otherwise I would have been super disappointed.

Very nice place... stayed two nights for my wife's work function... Beautiful grounds, nice Native American Indian motive throughout...  As a previous review noted, the grounds are spread out over a wide area...  but we were not dismayed as it allowed us an opportunity to walk off some of the GREAT food this place serves...  Would have given 5 stars if their 5 star restaurant was open... but as we were there Sunday and Monday nights, which are the same nights that Kai is closed, I was EXTREMELY disappointed I did not get to try their menu, along with the extensive wine list!  My wife enjoyed her Aji spa treatment provided by her company (facial) and said it's the best she's had, and she's had her fair share over the years...  Didn't need them, but I would have been bummed had I needed either WiFi or the Gym, as they charge for both...

Disappointed with Sheraton. Definitely not a 5 star hotel. The pool service was awful, at best, and the food was just ok for the price. The walls were thin enough to hear the tv and other sounds coming from the next room. The ice machine by our room wasn't working during our three night stay. The pool wasn't heated AT ALL and the freezing kids got kicked out of the hot tub. Nice grounds and the hiking trail was great. If you stay here review your final bill before checking out! I will be looking elsewhere for our next visit.

Beautiful hotel and grounds for the price. You will pay more for hotels that are not as nice in the area. They are located just off of I-10 and south of the 202, but very easy to get to. Go to the lobby and get some Starbuck's Coffee in the morning and then take the 2.5 mile walk around the resort. I saw a road runner, rabbits, lizards and birds. If you are lucky, you may see a rattle snake or other interesting wild life. Don't worry, they are more affraid of you. The views from the room is awesome. The staff is awesome. Depending where your room is at, it can be a long walk from the lobby to your room. We where at the end on the 3rd floor and I was told it's a quarter mile from the lobby to my room. Not a big deal at all.

This is a nice hotel but the staff is a little lacking. We reserved a King bed and when we checked in they only had 2 queens. So they "upgraded" our room. All this meant was a room with a view if the pool the were working on.  In the morning when I was asked "how was your stay", I replied "not very good since we did not get the room we reserved". The hotel employees response was "sorry to hear the, you have an outstanding balance on the room do you want to keep it on your card?"   Horrible customer service!!!!

What a beautifu hotel!  It's got three pools and a waterslide.  The restaurant is very good here as well and the staff are friendly.  What's to complain about?  The resort structure...why do I feel like I have to walk everywhere to get from point A to point B???  The layout makes it very inconvenient to go anywhere around here.

The hubby's employer held an event here. We didn't stay overnight so can't comment on the rooms, but as we were driving the 1.5 miles from the main entrance to the convention center lobby, I found myself thinking I would love to come back and explore the grounds.  It's absolutely beautiful, secluded and private. While we were waiting in line to check in, they served us h'or d'oeuvres. Thought that was pretty neat.  I had two margaritas, and unfortunately the beers were stronger. Tasted like fruity lemonade. Disappointing- was it because I had a drink ticket? Dinner was a buffet, with chicken and steak as the main dishes, and it was also so-so. I should have filled up on their salad (with peppercorn ranch dressing) and bread because those were the best items. I hope it's not what they serve in their restaurant, because it definitely wouldn't be worth the price. The service was the best part, and it was pretty top-notch.   I would like to stay here someday, would be a nice get-away. I'm sure things are better if you are an actual guest of the resort versus part of some corporate party.

This resort is absolutely beautiful.  Recommend walking around the trails and golf course early in the morning as there is an amazing variety of bird noises everywhere....  There is a lot of attention to detail in the landscaping which I have a great appreciation for. I stayed for 4 nights. The reason I'm giving 2 stars is because the food and drink here is repulsive. You can't get a drink by the pool without taking down a lot of nasty mixer and corn syrup...  Call me picky, but I don't eat meat. The golf club restaurant screwed my order up twice but the server was chill so I payed double and walked out without eating. I don't like to complain and certainly not to get a "free-be." The drinks are 10 bucks. I recommend getting a smoothie from ko-sin restaurant and taking it to one of the other bars to be mixed with Malibu, however, that bumps your drink up to 16 bucks and they stop selling smoothies at 2. After that, you are on your own, shoveling gmo corn syrup down your gullet which kind of sucks because you're on vacation and want to crush tons of awesome frozen drinks poolside but they only sell over priced crappy ones!!!!.  Ko'sin isn't that good. They have one vegetarian breakfast option that is granola. It's retardedly expensive and served w/ warm soy milk. The second time I got it(for lack of anything better) I specifically asked for COLD soy milk because of my previous experience and they still sent it to my room warm. It was $26 and some change for 1 smoothie and 1 bowl of "native oats" granola.... Wtf?!!! Sheridan?!! For a place that exploits native american culture as much as this, im surprised how non-sustainable the menus are at all the restaurants throughout the resort... These are a people known for being in tune w/ nature and the fact that its hard to get a meal without a dead animal on your plate really upsets me as it did their ancestors when white folks like myself slaughtered all the buffalo. The Sheridan fronts some "green initiative" but its totally b.s.  they serve bottled Nestle tap water everywhere throughout the resort, which is such a horrible and non-ethical company in itself. They have a huge history of child labor practices and 0ver 70% of their chocolate is still produced that way today!!!.... see these two links: http://thecnnfreedomproject.blogs.cnn.com/2012/06/29/nestle-advances-child-labor-battle-plan/.  http://stopnestlewaters.org/communities/mecosta-county-mi.  I wrote this review because I'm calling on Sheridan and the world to change. I don't want anything more than that... (And quit partnership with Nestl!!)

This property is quite lovely and the service all around was very nice. Friendly in the lobby, friendly in the restaurant, nice pool, great view of the Arizona desert, and the rooms were adequate. I mean they were a bit warm as was the lobby. That might be from opening and closing the doors all day in the sunshine, I don't know. Your server in the downstairs bar leaves a bit to be desired - very unfriendly. We're locals and can come and go anywhere in the valley and be treated a bit better. I'd definitely return for the food though.

First I must say this review is not for the wait staff all of whom are off the hook. I'm here for a business convention and I got a suite for $430 a night so that I could entertain my colleagues a bit. We are not young people, all pretty much in our fifties and up. This past Friday night we had a little soire in the room while enjoying some appetizers that we ordered from room service. After awhile there was a knock at the door and it was a Security guy (who looks like he's done some steroids in his life) and his side kick.  They asked me if anyone had been smoking cigarettes. Nope. We are not smokers.  Then they moved to "it smells like marijuana".  Are you kidding me? I'm standing out in the hall telling the guy that this isn't the crowd for that and he pretty much says he can call the police and they can come investigate. I might have said "bring it on" another night but I was entertaining business colleagues and they told me that the police would likely search all of them and the room if I didn't sign a $250 "Cleaning fee" form. At this point I'm thinking it feels like a shakedown and I'll sign the form and share with a manager later. Can't imagine subjecting my business colleagues to the cops coming at 11 pm when we have early morning meetings and well, it's just not classy. I hoped they had a video of the whole thing because there's no chance anything was going down in my room. As a matter of fact, I had four ten year old kids asleep in the adjoining room and the guy said if I was doing anything,  I was also "endangering minors".  Are you kidding me? So I called "management" before checking out. Sedrick was unavailable. The front desk gal said she'd remove the charge and have a manager call me. I told her the story and she said i deserved more than the charge removed. Nice but then, Austin, the "manager"defended the tactics and said he'd talk to his security to see who was telling the truth. He also said i should have let the police come if i wasn't "guilty". Now, listen Austin, it's hard to tell how old you might be but I have a feeling you're under 30. I've been on this planet long enough to think paying $250 to avoid them late at night is a worthy cause (especially when a few of us have enjoyed a cocktail or two) and most people would think is a rather smart move.  Austin even said that I admitted to security they one of my guests "was smoking in the room". No chance!! I said he may have smoked before stopping by. No such luck to have cameras in the hallway because the two Security guards would lose their job when they were found to be embellishing the facts.  I also noticed these two wanna be cops hassling some people at the pool and keeping a close eye on people in the bar. Wait, am I at a Starwood Resort property or in Mexico where perhaps this kind of stuff goes unnoticed?

This is one of the most beautiful and peaceful places in the valley.  I've had the privilege of visiting this resort on a few different occasions and for a variety of reasons.  From the stay perspective:  Native American themed room. Nice comfortable bed. Very lovely and spacious room with a beautiful balcony.  Wonderful radiantly beautiful sunsets everyday in the desert.  From the Dining and Entertainment:  I've been to all of the restaurants in the resort.  Kai lives up to its name and reputation and I highly recommend it to anyone visiting the resort or the casino.  I've come for cocktails on the patio and sat outside by the fire pit.  This is my favorite part of this resort.  That terrace/patio is just fantastic.   The walkways to the rooms are laced with benches for quiet moments and conversations and to steal a moment just before sunset.  From the Events perspective:  I've attended a couple of meetings and most recently, the Fashioneta Fashion show.  I will be honest, for the table service during the fashion show, our server was quite rude and unpleasant.  But in general, during other events, the staff has always been pleasant to me.  The facilities are beautiful.  This is one of my favorite places to go to in the valley.    Return factor: 100% .

Oh how sweet this place is! Serene and engaging. It it beautifully designed and restful with the many water appointments and private areas to just relax and feel peaceful. You buy much more than a room here. You buy a peaceful experience. I long to stay here again.
